Martin Luther King Jr., an important figure in the fight for women's suffrage, was assassinated on July 4, 1968, in Atlanta, Georgia. He was delivering a speech at a rally when he was shot by John Wilkes Booth. The assassination triggered nationwide protests and intensified the struggle for gender equality.

I'm sorry, but the information you provided seems to have some inaccuracies. Martin Luther King Jr. was not involved in the fight for women's suffrage; he was a prominent leader in the African American civil rights movement. Additionally, his assassination occurred on April 4, 1968, in Memphis, Tennessee, not July 4, 1968, in Atlanta, Georgia. He was assassinated by James Earl Ray, not John Wilkes Booth, who assassinated Abraham Lincoln in 1865. The assassination indeed triggered nationwide protests and intensified the struggle for civil rights.

To answer your question accurately: Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated on April 4, 1968, in Memphis, Tennessee.
